The ruling, by US District Judge Peter J. Messitte in Maryland, marks the first time a lawsuit of this kind has cleared the initial legal hurdle. Messitte cited examples of government clients, including Bahrain and Kuwait, patronising the Trump International Hotel in Washington, which may have had an illegal effect on competition. The Jefferson Memorial in Washington DC, is suffering from the presence of biofilm, a blackening effect found on monuments around the world. The problem is caused by natural weathering on the marble blocks of the Memorial, which has turned them into the perfect environment for biofilm to grow. A team of conservators, architects and molecular biologists has been studying the growth since 2014, as they prepare to test potential treatment options. The National Park Service officials have recently begun testing ten different chemical biocides in small patches affected by biofilm at the base of the Memorial and will also experiment with non-traditional treatment options, including ozonated water and irradiation with lasers.

House Bill 2036 forbids doctors from aborting most fetuses with a gestational age of 20 weeks or older, even in situations where the doctor discovers the fetus has a fatal defect. The law also defines gestational age as beginning on the first day of the woman's last period, meaning abortions are actually banned starting at 18 weeks of pregnancy. Arizona is the only state with a law pushing the ban back to 18 weeks into the pregnancy. Under the Bankruptcy Code, an assignee of personal property who elects not to enforce an assignor's lien, under § 10(a), will nevertheless be responsible for the unpaid debt if the assignee fails to file a timely petition seeking a modification of the judgment.[12] See, e. g., 21 U. S. C. § 7403. But this case does not involve an assignee of personal property who elects not to enforce the assignor's lien, because respondent has no claim that § 10(a) bars his equitable claim. The Bankruptcy Code provides that the "liens of any person... upon property shall attach only to such person." § 10(a)(2). The Court of Appeals correctly held that the District Court lacked jurisdiction to issue a garnishment order against respondent.

Knox and her co-defendant, Raffaele Sollecito, are in the final stages of a second appeal against convictions handed down in 2009. Knox confirmed in an interview that she has no intention of returning to Italy if the verdict goes against her.
